Costs:
No trip to Sardinia is complete without a walk through the maquis, with
its sweet-smelling carpet of scented flora. You’ll find this typical
Mediterranean vegetation in coastal and mountainous regions, including
Gennargentu National Park and the island of San Pietro. Visit in spring,
when the aroma is at its strongest.
Description:
Speckled with caves, subterranean Sardinia is a magical realm of
shimmering limestone formations. The most enchanting of all is the vast
Grotta di Nettuno (see Capo Caccia), which encases the crystal-clear
waters of Lake Marmora – once home to monk seals. You can explore this
atmospheric space on foot, along illuminated walkways, or experience a
seal’s-eye view of its depths on a diving excursion.
Equipment:
Sardinia’s highest and most magnificent sea stack is Pan di Zucchero (Sugarloaf).
Rising out of the bright blue sea, this dramatically steep limestone rock is only a
few hundred metres from the shore.

when it almost appears to glow
RelatedEvents.Name: Hike in Lombachertal

RelatedEvents.Description:
The mountains, valleys and coastal waters of Sardinia are
teeming with wildlife, including a surprising number of rare
species.
RelatedEvents.Name: Hike to Montblank

SubImages.Description:
Encounter herds of stocky wild horses and vivid flocks
of pink flamingos as you explore the varied habitats of this
natural wonderland.
SubImages.Name: Flamingos

Transportation:
There’s no shortage of spectacular scenery on the coast, but the dazzling
Piscinas Dunes are in a league all of their own.
